Chapter 2 Random Variables Review 2.1 Univariate Random variables:URV A random variable is always a measurable function as we present in the following definition. Definition 2.1 (Univariate Random variable) Let \((\Omega, \mathcal{A},P)\) be a probability space. A function \[\begin{equation*} X:\Omega\rightarrow \mathbb{R} \end{equation*}\] is called a random variable if the inverse image under \(X\) of all Borel sets in \(\mathbb{R}\) are events. That is, \[\begin{equation*} X^{-1}(B)=\lbrace \omega: X(w) \in B \rbrace \in \mathcal{A} \qquad \forall B \in \beta (\mathbb{R}) \end{equation*}\] Note: usually we use \(B=(-\infty,x])\) Example 2.1 (A coin) Let \(\Omega=\lbrace H,T \rbrace\), and \(\mathcal{A}\) be the class of all subsets of \(\Omega\). Define \(X\) by \(X(H)=1, X(T)=0\). Then, \[\begin{equation} X^{-1}(-\infty, x] = \begin{cases} \emptyset, & \text{if $x<0$ } \\ \{T\}, & \text{if $0\leq x<1$}\\ \{H,T \}, & \text{if $x\geq 1$.} \end{cases} \end{equation}\] and we see that \(X\) is a RV. Example 2.2 (Two coins) Let \(\Omega=\{ HH, TT, HT,TH\}\) and \(\mathcal{A}\) be the class of all subsets of \(\Omega\). Define \(X\) by: \(X(\omega)=\) Number of Heads in \(\omega\). Then \(X(HH)=2\), \(X(HT)=X(TH)=1\), and \(X(TT)=0\). \[\begin{equation} X^{-1}(-\infty, x] \begin{cases} \emptyset, & \text{if $x<0$ } \\ \{TT\}, & \text{if $0\leq x<1$}\\ \{TH,HT\},& \text{if $1\leq x<2$,}\\ \{HH \}, & \text{if $x\geq 2$.} \end{cases} \end{equation}\] 2.2 Discrete Variable Definition 2.2 (Discrete Variable) A random variable defined on \((\Omega, \mathcal{A} , P)\) is said to be discrete type, or simple discrete, if there exist a countable set \(B\subseteq \mathbb{R}\) such that \(P(x \in B)=1\). The elements of \(B\) will be called possible values of \(X\). And usually are denoted by \[ X=\{x_1,\ldots,x_n\} \] 2.3 Probability Mass Function Definition 2.3 (Probability Mass Function ) The function \(P_X: \mathbb{R} \longrightarrow [0,1]\) defined by \[\begin{equation*} P_X(X=x)=P\circ X^{-1} (x)=P(X^{-1} (x))=P\{\omega\in \Omega:X(\omega)=x\} \end{equation*}\] Is called {}. Or the collection of number \(\{ p_i\rbrace\) satisfying, \(P(\lbrace X= x_i\} )= p_i \geq 0\), for all i and \(\sum \limits_{i=1}^\infty p_i =1\), is called The Probability Mass Function (PMF) of RV \(X\). Definition 2.4 (Distribution Probability Mass Function) The distribution Function of \(x\) is given by \[\begin{equation} f_X(x)=P_X(X\leq x)=\sum _{y\leq x} P_X{(y)} \end{equation}\] Find the \(F(x)\) for a random variable \(X\) with pmf \[\begin{equation} f_X(x) = \begin{cases} \frac{1}{7}, & \text{if $x=-2$,} \\ \frac{3}{7}, & \text{if $x=\frac{1}{2}$,} \\ \frac{3}{7}, & \text{if $x=\sqrt{2} $,}\\ 0, & \mbox{Otherwise.} \end{cases} \end{equation}\] Example 2.3 (DF of a variable X) If the DF of X is given by: \[\begin{equation} F_X(x) = \begin{cases} 0, & \mbox{if $x<-2$,} \\ \frac{1}{7}, & \mbox{if $-2\leq x< 2$,} \\ \frac{4}{7}, & \mbox{if $\frac{1}{2}\leq x < \sqrt{2} $,}\\ 1, & \mbox{if $x\geq \sqrt{2}$.} \end{cases} \end{equation}\] Given \(F(x)\) What is \(f_X(x)\) ? Remember that \[\begin{eqnarray*} P_X(X=x)&=&P_X(x)\\ &=&F_X(x)-F_X(x^-) \qquad \forall x\in \mathbb{R} \end{eqnarray*}\] That is, the DF of a RV \(X\), completely determine the density probability function.
